user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of deinit_data:
```c
static void
deinit_data (void)
{
  if (NULL != resp_single)
    MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
  resp_single = NULL;
  if (NULL != resps)
  {
    unsigned int i;
    for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
      MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
    num_resps = 0;
    free (resps);
  }
  resps = NULL;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call MHD_destroy_response(resp_single) is executed when resp_single != NULL and thus is reachable at runtime. A specific violation of Rule 2.1 would occur if the statement were placed in code that can never execute — for example, after an unconditional return, after an infinite loop, or inside a conditional that is provably always false (e.g. #if 0 or if (0) { MHD_destroy_response(resp_single); }) — which is not the case here.
